text_blocks: The sky seldom sees alike this age, | Which hurts the heart of Jibreel, the sage.
What a good temple there he makes, | Whom ‘momin’ adores and ‘Kafir’ fakes.
poems.full_text:
The sky seldom sees alike this age, | Which hurts the heart of Jibreel, the sage.
What a good temple there he makes, | Whom ‘momin’ adores and ‘Kafir’ fakes.
phrases: ‘momin’:         Momin faithful
‘Kafir’:         Kafir infidel.

text_blocks: Get me Seenay’s truth, and love of his name, | Get me Rumi’s fame and Khisro’s flame.
In obeisance mould I have cast my frame, | I shun any offer of godship’s game.
poems.full_text:
Get me Seenay’s truth, and love of his name, | Get me Rumi’s fame and Khisro’s flame.
In obeisance mould I have cast my frame, | I shun any offer of godship’s game.
phrases: Seenay’s:         Seenay: Hakim Sinai-ee, known for his philosophy and poetry, full name Abut Majd Mujaddad Ghaznavi, born in 5th c. Hijra, was a court poet of Sultan Behram Shah Ghazni, was living there like slaves. He became a disciple of Kh: Abu Yusuf Hamdani who made a true paragon of virtue and knowledge, that the King himself became his devoted adorer. Rumi eulogizes him in a verse.

Khisro’s:         Khisro Khwaja Abul Hasan of Delhi, one of the nobles of the King, was titled as Bulbul-i-Hind (A nightingale of India), was a disciple of Kh: Nizam-ud-Din, whose mausoleum in Delhi is visited by thousands daily.

text_blocks: A Muslim gloats in hunger and patches, | To Gabriel his deeds are sheer scratches.
Come, fashion and form a new nation’s norm, | This nation is a burden on world’s arm.
poems.full_text:
A Muslim gloats in hunger and patches, | To Gabriel his deeds are sheer scratches.
Come, fashion and form a new nation’s norm, | This nation is a burden on world’s arm.

text_blocks: A nation again whom duty is dear, | Who makes a clean honey from venom clear.
He agreed not on one world norm, | And held the two worlds on his arm.
poems.full_text:
A nation again whom duty is dear, | Who makes a clean honey from venom clear.
He agreed not on one world norm, | And held the two worlds on his arm.

text_blocks: A nation again whose hearts would adorn, | La Ilah’s jewels from midnight to morn.
Her place the sun knows on skies and lands, | And sweeps for her the milky way sands.
poems.full_text:
A nation again whose hearts would adorn, | La Ilah’s jewels from midnight to morn.
Her place the sun knows on skies and lands, | And sweeps for her the milky way sands.

text_blocks: Thy world is ruled by misers few, | Whose men still serve the worthless few.
The workers skilled in workshops queue, | Have killed themselves for vultures few.
poems.full_text:
Thy world is ruled by misers few, | Whose men still serve the worthless few.
The workers skilled in workshops queue, | Have killed themselves for vultures few.

text_blocks: A hungry seeker begged his Sheikh to plead, | Does God has no knowledge of peoples’ need.
To me he is closer than jugular vein, | But not closer than my abdomen’s pain.
poems.full_text:
A hungry seeker begged his Sheikh to plead, | Does God has no knowledge of peoples’ need.
To me he is closer than jugular vein, | But not closer than my abdomen’s pain.

text_blocks: Looking in a mess is Indian State, | In the same messy form is world’s own state.
So solicit not five times to pray, | A burden on slaves are these arrays.
poems.full_text:
Looking in a mess is Indian State, | In the same messy form is world’s own state.
So solicit not five times to pray, | A burden on slaves are these arrays.

text_blocks: From bondage a Moslem is a self sold guy, | A captive of charms of ear and eye.
How weak and sluggish in bondage are veins, | To God made Laws, we are seeing with pains.
poems.full_text:
From bondage a Moslem is a self sold guy, | A captive of charms of ear and eye.
How weak and sluggish in bondage are veins, | To God made Laws, we are seeing with pains.

text_blocks: So calculate once all the losses and gains, | To give to this world a heavenly reign.
How far I know not that dusty being we, | Can decorate world’s dusty entity.
poems.full_text:
So calculate once all the losses and gains, | To give to this world a heavenly reign.
How far I know not that dusty being we, | Can decorate world’s dusty entity.

text_blocks: What is the lasting life is known to thee, | A sudden death but is not known to thee.
Thy status at all it can not decrease, | What could be the loss of my deathless lease.
poems.full_text:
What is the lasting life is known to thee, | A sudden death but is not known to thee.
Thy status at all it can not decrease, | What could be the loss of my deathless lease.

text_blocks: When the old world gets its apex of height , | Then the fate unsheaths every secret might.
Disgrace me not before my master hence, | My! ‘counts book’! be hidden from Prophet thence.
poems.full_text:
When the old world gets its apex of height , | Then the fate unsheaths every secret might.
Disgrace me not before my master hence, | My! ‘counts book’! be hidden from Prophet thence.
phrases: height:         It means that his doom is getting near. Line 2 also conveys the same thought.

text_blocks: My body is tired but soul still flies, | To that city on way Batha lies.
You live here now and meet the fine, | My object great is friend of mine.
poems.full_text:
My body is tired but soul still flies, | To that city on way Batha lies.
You live here now and meet the fine, | My object great is friend of mine.
phrases: fine,:         You live here. The poet's soliloquy, while addressing his body.

text_blocks: O, tent chamberlain! leave the tent hark | The guide has gone beyond the base park .
To drive the litters now flops the-wan-brain, | I let the heart hence to take up the reins.
poems.full_text:
O, tent chamberlain! leave the tent hark | The guide has gone beyond the base park .
To drive the litters now flops the-wan-brain, | I let the heart hence to take up the reins.
phrases: park:         Iqbal takes the first line from a verse of Manuchehree, whose full name was Najam-ud-Din Ahmed s/o Yaqub Manuchehr. He was a courtier of Mehmud Ghaznavi, died in 1080 A.D. It is still customary to write an ellipsis (tazmin) on a verse of a poet without changing the central idea. (in India, Pakistan and Iran)

text_blocks: I keep my eyes penchant on hearts essence, | Though writhing I am resting on heart’s fence.
From cities and bergs I liked to flee, | To the deserts breeze I look up with glee.
poems.full_text:
I keep my eyes penchant on hearts essence, | Though writhing I am resting on heart’s fence.
From cities and bergs I liked to flee, | To the deserts breeze I look up with glee.

text_blocks: I know not who dazzled and killed this heart, | No rest since then is destined to this part.
I took him to desert which pained him more. | On a brook side too he be wept to the core.
poems.full_text:
I know not who dazzled and killed this heart, | No rest since then is destined to this part.
I took him to desert which pained him more. | On a brook side too he be wept to the core.
phrases: core.:         To the core; to the core of his heart.

text_blocks: Ask not of lustre drunk’s caravan scene, | They have left the world whole and all its means.
By God my feelings rouse from peals of bell, | As if the wind booms through canes wood deli.
poems.full_text:
Ask not of lustre drunk’s caravan scene, | They have left the world whole and all its means.
By God my feelings rouse from peals of bell, | As if the wind booms through canes wood deli.
phrases: drunk’s:         Lustre drunk lovers of God (Jalwa mastan; lost in the sheen of God by submerging in Him, drowned in Him, in a daze. (Lost in daze) From peals of bells; the pilgrims feel as if they would teach their destination soon. Thus the hells rouse their fervour and frenzy.

text_blocks: I cherish for Yasrib though I am old, | I am moved to singing in love’s sweet hold.
As the birds at dusk would fly back to nest, | I cherish to fly for the desert’s quest.
poems.full_text:
I cherish for Yasrib though I am old, | I am moved to singing in love’s sweet hold.
As the birds at dusk would fly back to nest, | I cherish to fly for the desert’s quest.
phrases: quest.:         quest in loneliness there.

text_blocks: To love’an rapture sins gave a common sense, | And made ripes’ wisdom a raws logic hence.
I sing songs hey! to Makkan tunes gay, | Since wine in cup was poured on the first day.
poems.full_text:
To love’an rapture sins gave a common sense, | And made ripes’ wisdom a raws logic hence.
I sing songs hey! to Makkan tunes gay, | Since wine in cup was poured on the first day.
phrases: rapture:         Some people tauntingly say that the mystic's Ishq and Masti (Love and raptures) is a sin a; they flee from responsibilities of life, which are al-o a must for every body.

ripes’: The 4th line of this quatrain has been taken by Iqbal from Iraqi, whose full name is Fakhr-ud-Din Ibrahim Iraqi. He died at Damascus in 688 Hijra, where he had finally settled. He also visited Multan with a hand of Qalandars (ascetics) and accepted the initiation of Khawaja Baha-ud-Din Zakriya.

day.: The 4th line of this quatrain has been taken by Iqbal from Iraqi, whose full name is Fakhr-ud-Din Ibrahim Iraqi. He died at Damascus in 688 Hijra, where he had finally settled. He also visited Multan with a hand of Qalandars (ascetics) and accepted the initiation of Khawaja Baha-ud-Din Zakriya.

text_blocks: You ask the spots where I played my jazz there, | My friends know little I came up from where.
I opened my baggage in desert’s heat, | Where I am singing in his lone retreat.
poems.full_text:
You ask the spots where I played my jazz there, | My friends know little I came up from where.
I opened my baggage in desert’s heat, | Where I am singing in his lone retreat.
phrases: there,:         (Literal):- You ask of places where I sang songs there.

text_blocks: That dawn I asked naqah not to run quick, | Its rider is feeble, too old and sick.
In a dancing prance move but she runs more , | That sand to her feet is a silky floor.
poems.full_text:
That dawn I asked naqah not to run quick, | Its rider is feeble, too old and sick.
In a dancing prance move but she runs more , | That sand to her feet is a silky floor.
phrases: more: (Literal) In a gaily way trot but she would say,
floor.: To her desert sand is a silky way. This is why she likes to run fast. That soil of Yasrib and Mecca is also dear to her!

text_blocks: She needs no reins O I teamster hence! | Like my own wits she has the same sense.
From its wavelike trot a plea I would form, | Like me she is captive of heart’s own charm.
poems.full_text:
She needs no reins O I teamster hence! | Like my own wits she has the same sense.
From its wavelike trot a plea I would form, | Like me she is captive of heart’s own charm.
phrases: charm.:         viz, she likes to reach quick to the Prophet's place.

text_blocks: Yet tears moist vivid in jet black eyes, | My heart thus burns from his morning sighs.
That burnt my conscience was the sole wine, | Flowing with his gaze like wavelets fine.
poems.full_text:
Yet tears moist vivid in jet black eyes, | My heart thus burns from his morning sighs.
That burnt my conscience was the sole wine, | Flowing with his gaze like wavelets fine.

text_blocks: How lucky are deserts caravan lines, | They bless the Prophet driving litters fine.
Cast thy kowtows on hot sand grains, | Burn thy forehead to form a stain.
poems.full_text:
How lucky are deserts caravan lines, | They bless the Prophet driving litters fine.
Cast thy kowtows on hot sand grains, | Burn thy forehead to form a stain.

text_blocks: Hail the desert whose eve is morning gay, | Whose nights are shorter and longer the day.
Place thy steps with a gentle gait, | That sands like me has a ruthful trait.
poems.full_text:
Hail the desert whose eve is morning gay, | Whose nights are shorter and longer the day.
Place thy steps with a gentle gait, | That sands like me has a ruthful trait.

text_blocks: Who’s that Ajmi as head of caravan | His tone varies from tune of desert’s man.
His tone up a charming, lilting song, | That a cold heart feels more young and strong.
poems.full_text:
Who’s that Ajmi as head of caravan | His tone varies from tune of desert’s man.
His tone up a charming, lilting song, | That a cold heart feels more young and strong.

text_blocks: A place in love and raptures was his aim, | Such fires were lit up in his muddy frame.
His cries chime in with every one’s heart, | That every one shares his heart’s good part.
poems.full_text:
A place in love and raptures was his aim, | Such fires were lit up in his muddy frame.
His cries chime in with every one’s heart, | That every one shares his heart’s good part.

text_blocks: A hidden grief untold is clear, | To lips when brought, a tale-we hear-,
The ways are like a maze, seeker is weak, | The lamp blown out, night amidst, also bleak.
poems.full_text:
A hidden grief untold is clear, | To lips when brought, a tale-we hear-,
The ways are like a maze, seeker is weak, | The lamp blown out, night amidst, also bleak.

text_blocks: In pits grow poppies from vernal tide, | Then the friends pitch tents on desert’s side.
It looks me nice to sit all alone, | When fountains flow in a mountain zone.
poems.full_text:
In pits grow poppies from vernal tide, | Then the friends pitch tents on desert’s side.
It looks me nice to sit all alone, | When fountains flow in a mountain zone.

text_blocks: A page of Iraqi sometimes I turn, | From Jami’s fire so often I burn.
I know not though the Arabs’ tune, | I share with joy the teamaster’s tune.
poems.full_text:
A page of Iraqi sometimes I turn, | From Jami’s fire so often I burn.
I know not though the Arabs’ tune, | I share with joy the teamaster’s tune.
phrases: Iraqi:         Imam Fakhr-ud-Din known as Iraqi (of Iraq), a mystic poet.

Jami’s:         Jami Maulana Abdul Rehman Of Kharjrohmin, a town in Jam province of Persia, born in Sha'ban 817 H, died in 808 H in Muharram, wrote 54-books on various topics, some were text books in scholastic school Teamster; a driver of camels.

teamaster’s:         Jami Maulana Abdul Rehman Of Kharjrohmin, a town in Jam province of Persia, born in Sha'ban 817 H, died in 808 H in Muharram, wrote 54-books on various topics, some were text books in scholastic school Teamster; a driver of camels.

text_blocks: Let the hiker’s grief take a blissful turn, | Let wails be blessed with rapturous burn.
O teamaster be ready for longer course, | Let separation pangs had sharper force.
poems.full_text:
Let the hiker’s grief take a blissful turn, | Let wails be blessed with rapturous burn.
O teamaster be ready for longer course, | Let separation pangs had sharper force.

text_blocks: Come O! chum for a tie to weep and cry. | A victim of ‘Beauty’ are you and I.
Two words I would say in hearts parlance, | By ‘Master’s’ feet let eyes go to trance.
poems.full_text:
Come O! chum for a tie to weep and cry. | A victim of ‘Beauty’ are you and I.
Two words I would say in hearts parlance, | By ‘Master’s’ feet let eyes go to trance.
phrases: ‘Beauty’:         Beauty the Gracious Beauty; the God or Prophet.
parlance,:         Parlance the way of speaking.

text_blocks: To wise he gave less wealth and affluence, | The duffer got lustres of raptures hence.
How lucky they were and lucky that age, | When king’s door were open to a saint or page.
poems.full_text:
To wise he gave less wealth and affluence, | The duffer got lustres of raptures hence.
How lucky they were and lucky that age, | When king’s door were open to a saint or page.

text_blocks: The world with four sides I have in arm-pit, | I have wrapped in this head the heavens’ wit.
Then I had to leave that topmost height, | Like dust my wing’s lost that higher flight.
poems.full_text:
The world with four sides I have in arm-pit, | I have wrapped in this head the heavens’ wit.
Then I had to leave that topmost height, | Like dust my wing’s lost that higher flight.

text_blocks: In this valley lies a lasting life new, | This dust solves meanings’ with an arcane clue.
The Sages and Moses are side by side, | There none would ever look a “Can’t see” slide.
poems.full_text:
In this valley lies a lasting life new, | This dust solves meanings’ with an arcane clue.
The Sages and Moses are side by side, | There none would ever look a “Can’t see” slide.
phrases: meanings’:         In Persian 'Mayani' (or meanings) also mean talents, higher faculties, intrinsic qualities etc.

see”:         Can't see is a reference to when God said to Moses, You cannot see me. This dust grows meanings in shapeless form (is the literal version) in that case 1st line's last word would be "norm'.

text_blocks: A Muslim was a king and saint so high, | (Flows from his bosom a flame of sigh)
His heart often weeps why weeps in trance, | A glance upon me O Prophet, a glance.
poems.full_text:
A Muslim was a king and saint so high, | (Flows from his bosom a flame of sigh)
His heart often weeps why weeps in trance, | A glance upon me O Prophet, a glance.

text_blocks: The heart takes heat from thy love pangs’ flame, | My tone’s large impact is due to thy name.
I weep, because, in the Indian state, | I found not a man with thee intimate.
poems.full_text:
The heart takes heat from thy love pangs’ flame, | My tone’s large impact is due to thy name.
I weep, because, in the Indian state, | I found not a man with thee intimate.

text_blocks: No morn yet to slaves O Indian night, | The sun passes not along this land’s site,
No cosy nook yet for us in the East, | So broke like a Muslim there is no beast.
poems.full_text:
No morn yet to slaves O Indian night, | The sun passes not along this land’s site,
No cosy nook yet for us in the East, | So broke like a Muslim there is no beast.
phrases: broke:         viz, helpless; poor.

text_blocks: As such I say to a. soft hearted soul, | A Muslim is honoured on virtues role.
O God, help the man who leads a life hard, | Who fell from a summit, God be his ward.
poems.full_text:
As such I say to a. soft hearted soul, | A Muslim is honoured on virtues role.
O God, help the man who leads a life hard, | Who fell from a summit, God be his ward.
phrases: soul,:         Iqbal says, "As such I say to a poor (meek) ruthful man among the mystics-A Faqir is not actually poor but a voluntary-poor, leads a life like a poor fellow, who actually likes to help the poor to remove their poverty". Where Iqbal says 'A poor man' he means the same. There is no equivalent word to convey this sense in English language as I understand. His 'Faqir' is not a beggar nor a mendicant, but a man who hikes to distribute every penny to the poor.

text_blocks: A friend’s hidden life how can I reveal, | You know what we talk and what we conceal.
Two hundred years’ tale is enough to weep, | Like a butcher’s wood a heart I keep.
poems.full_text:
A friend’s hidden life how can I reveal, | You know what we talk and what we conceal.
Two hundred years’ tale is enough to weep, | Like a butcher’s wood a heart I keep.

text_blocks: The sky still going on a perverse course, | The car’avan is far off from its place.
His wild goose chases I cannot endorse, | No leader they have to direct this race.
poems.full_text:
The sky still going on a perverse course, | The car’avan is far off from its place.
His wild goose chases I cannot endorse, | No leader they have to direct this race.
phrases: sky:         The Persian poets, (so the Indo-Pakistani), always symbolise 'sky' going on a perverse policy against the inhabitants of earth. As such literal translation was a necessity to enjoy the true sense.

text_blocks: In his pure blood shines not that vigour and heat, | In his ruined land grows no poppies sweet.
He emptied his pocket and sheath likewise, | In a ruined arch thus his Book still lies.
poems.full_text:
In his pure blood shines not that vigour and heat, | In his ruined land grows no poppies sweet.
He emptied his pocket and sheath likewise, | In a ruined arch thus his Book still lies.

text_blocks: He made his heart captive of pomp and show, | Bereft of love’s pleasures his longings go.
The ‘whistling’ of ‘eagles’ he knew a few, | As nature of gnats his latent ears knew.
poems.full_text:
He made his heart captive of pomp and show, | Bereft of love’s pleasures his longings go.
The ‘whistling’ of ‘eagles’ he knew a few, | As nature of gnats his latent ears knew.

text_blocks: To him the heart’s door is not open yet, | No ego in his palm has born as yet.
His conscience is empty from ‘Great God’ calls, | To ground have fallen his prayer’s four walls.
poems.full_text:
To him the heart’s door is not open yet, | No ego in his palm has born as yet.
His conscience is empty from ‘Great God’ calls, | To ground have fallen his prayer’s four walls.
phrases: palm:         Palm or dusty palm is not used in English. It is better to use 'heart' in this place.

text_blocks: His collar is torn, he cares no darn, | I know not a life, so bore, forlorn.
To him is destined, a death so dry, | Fie a Muslim’s life, sans ‘Allah Hoo’ cry.
poems.full_text:
His collar is torn, he cares no darn, | I know not a life, so bore, forlorn.
To him is destined, a death so dry, | Fie a Muslim’s life, sans ‘Allah Hoo’ cry.

text_blocks: Give him his dues, of a captive and meek, | A beggar whose honour is since long dead.
The doors of a tavern are closed on weak, | The Muslims are dying from thirst on bed.
poems.full_text:
Give him his dues, of a captive and meek, | A beggar whose honour is since long dead.
The doors of a tavern are closed on weak, | The Muslims are dying from thirst on bed.

text_blocks: Refine his morals and life once more, | Infuse a world new in his heart’s core.
From violent storms, his clothes are torn, | Fear from his lamp, though wavers and worn.
poems.full_text:
Refine his morals and life once more, | Infuse a world new in his heart’s core.
From violent storms, his clothes are torn, | Fear from his lamp, though wavers and worn.

text_blocks: The bride of life, in him is not his own, | She comes out then from limbe’s lover line.
Entombed before death like sinner in chain, | Torn among the angels of church and fane.
poems.full_text:
The bride of life, in him is not his own, | She comes out then from limbe’s lover line.
Entombed before death like sinner in chain, | Torn among the angels of church and fane.

text_blocks: His eyes are void of a glamour and glee, | No restive heart in his bosom I see.
God be a friend of the unlucky race, | Who vanished from scene being out of His grace.
poems.full_text:
His eyes are void of a glamour and glee, | No restive heart in his bosom I see.
God be a friend of the unlucky race, | Who vanished from scene being out of His grace.

text_blocks: Though born as Muslim yet knows not the death, | From fear of death shivers to his last breath
I didn’t peep though through his bosom’s slit | The fear of death has weaken’d his grit.
poems.full_text:
Though born as Muslim yet knows not the death, | From fear of death shivers to his last breath
I didn’t peep though through his bosom’s slit | The fear of death has weaken’d his grit.

text_blocks: The kingship as whole is trick and skill, | In Rome or Jeddah none safe from his kill.
The sufferings of friends I say not to thee, | In hope thy solace would make me happy.
poems.full_text:
The kingship as whole is trick and skill, | In Rome or Jeddah none safe from his kill.
The sufferings of friends I say not to thee, | In hope thy solace would make me happy.

text_blocks: A Muslim’s stuff has a life long stay, | His lay out stands on a powerful clay.
O wise critique see him from his view, | The ‘Ego’ in him now shakes all through.
poems.full_text:
A Muslim’s stuff has a life long stay, | His lay out stands on a powerful clay.
O wise critique see him from his view, | The ‘Ego’ in him now shakes all through.

text_blocks: Ashamed is Muslim for losing his State, | His dead faith is haunting some hermits great.
You know their bequest and forefather’s line, | He holds his ‘blanket’ as a kingship sign.
poems.full_text:
Ashamed is Muslim for losing his State, | His dead faith is haunting some hermits great.
You know their bequest and forefather’s line, | He holds his ‘blanket’ as a kingship sign.

text_blocks: Ask me not of his present day lot, | As if, earth and sky have made a plot,
To bird who was reared on fruits of fig, | The grains’ search in deserts a problem big.
poems.full_text:
Ask me not of his present day lot, | As if, earth and sky have made a plot,
To bird who was reared on fruits of fig, | The grains’ search in deserts a problem big.

text_blocks: I have scanned the whole world through his eye, | So past and future tips I would untie.
Thus ope more and more life’s secret tips, | Give the Arab’s tone on this Ajmi’s1 lips.
poems.full_text:
I have scanned the whole world through his eye, | So past and future tips I would untie.
Thus ope more and more life’s secret tips, | Give the Arab’s tone on this Ajmi’s1 lips.

text_blocks: The Muslims have raised no armament wings, | His conscience is yet like conscience of kings.
If he gets back his status again, | Through his beauty his grandeur would reign.
poems.full_text:
The Muslims have raised no armament wings, | His conscience is yet like conscience of kings.
If he gets back his status again, | Through his beauty his grandeur would reign.

text_blocks: The assets of Sheikh were the fables old, | On guess and thinking his Hadith was mould.
He holds faith yet like a Hindu’s thread , | His mosque thus sways in a temple’s stead.
poems.full_text:
The assets of Sheikh were the fables old, | On guess and thinking his Hadith was mould.
He holds faith yet like a Hindu’s thread , | His mosque thus sways in a temple’s stead.
phrases: Sheikh:         Assets of Sheikh viz, the canonist, who issues rescripts on doctrinal points.
guess:         Zan; conjecture supposition.
thread:         Hindu's thread; as worn by Brehmans like rosary of Muslims and Christians is called a Jan'a Ou: in Hindi and Sanskrit.

text_blocks: He brought a total change in faithless world, | They say, “body is a track for life’s bird ”
With ‘faqr’ thou destined to the Siddiq’s part, | May fill a new thrill to this ease loving heart.
poems.full_text:
He brought a total change in faithless world, | They say, “body is a track for life’s bird ”
With ‘faqr’ thou destined to the Siddiq’s part, | May fill a new thrill to this ease loving heart.
phrases: say,:         They say. viz, the scientists.
bird:         Life's bird; soul.
‘faqr’:         Faqr; Ascetic nature (not poverty), a love of simple life.
Siddiq’s:         Siddiq Hazrat Abu Bakr as-Siddiq.

text_blocks: From fane gets Harem its grandeur and glare, | My ‘idol’ is a ‘pir’ with curly hair.
None ill-starred came in my bosom’s frame, | Being lit up with light of his hopeful flame.
poems.full_text:
From fane gets Harem its grandeur and glare, | My ‘idol’ is a ‘pir’ with curly hair.
None ill-starred came in my bosom’s frame, | Being lit up with light of his hopeful flame.
phrases: ‘pir’:         Pirak, a 'pir' contemptuously; viz, my guide is a 'pir'.
flame.:         His hopeful flame; of the Prophet (Salam)

text_blocks: As long in mosque the poor kept a row, | They tore the emperors collars he
That fire when cooled in his heart and soul, | They crawled to tombs of saints to roll.
poems.full_text:
As long in mosque the poor kept a row, | They tore the emperors collars he
That fire when cooled in his heart and soul, | They crawled to tombs of saints to roll.
phrases: row,:         A row or rows of five time prayers.
roll.:         To roll around.

text_blocks: The Moslems are fighting with brothers own, | Save seeds of rupture nothing they have sown.
If you take a brick they raise cry and hue, | A mosque from which they are fleeing all through.
poems.full_text:
The Moslems are fighting with brothers own, | Save seeds of rupture nothing they have sown.
If you take a brick they raise cry and hue, | A mosque from which they are fleeing all through.

text_blocks: To others than God we touch our brows, | And sing like Guibers in round about rows.
I weep not on else, I weep on me, | We are not fit for honours of thee.
poems.full_text:
To others than God we touch our brows, | And sing like Guibers in round about rows.
I weep not on else, I weep on me, | We are not fit for honours of thee.
phrases: Guibers:         Guibers; a fire worshipper, followers of Zoroaster, who was also a Prophet, most probably
me,:         on myself.

text_blocks: In the hands of drinkers the empty glass, | My party’s bearer is jobless alas.
I keep an eye on sigh’s inner seat, | Whose source are the fumes of that lamp’s heat.
poems.full_text:
In the hands of drinkers the empty glass, | My party’s bearer is jobless alas.
I keep an eye on sigh’s inner seat, | Whose source are the fumes of that lamp’s heat.

text_blocks: The synagogues bottles are void of wine, | Where teachers are the pupils of that line.
The poets group I left with tears, | Their fifes and flutes are dead on ears.
poems.full_text:
The synagogues bottles are void of wine, | Where teachers are the pupils of that line.
The poets group I left with tears, | Their fifes and flutes are dead on ears.

text_blocks: The Muslims are foreigns on every land, | Are looked on this earth like a useless band.
Though powerless still I twist and twine, | I face the godless in every line.
poems.full_text:
The Muslims are foreigns on every land, | Are looked on this earth like a useless band.
Though powerless still I twist and twine, | I face the godless in every line.

text_blocks: With wings you gave I judge and fly, | In heat of songs I burn and cry.
A Muslim from whom shivers the death, | I found him not on whole earth’s breadth.
poems.full_text:
With wings you gave I judge and fly, | In heat of songs I burn and cry.
A Muslim from whom shivers the death, | I found him not on whole earth’s breadth.

text_blocks: At night before Lord I often cry, | Why Moslems are aimed for curse of sky.
A voice came then, “You know not this race, | Hold a heart yet know not lovers face.”
poems.full_text:
At night before Lord I often cry, | Why Moslems are aimed for curse of sky.
A voice came then, “You know not this race, | Hold a heart yet know not lovers face.”

text_blocks: I speak not now of the grandeur past. | No use to count now what did not last.’
I keep a lamp lit in chest of mine, | In two hundred years we sapped its shine.
poems.full_text:
I speak not now of the grandeur past. | No use to count now what did not last.’
I keep a lamp lit in chest of mine, | In two hundred years we sapped its shine.

text_blocks: The guard of Harem is the mason of fane, | His faith is dead, eyes set on others lane.
From his winking eyes it can be seen, | He is despaired of all godsend means.
poems.full_text:
The guard of Harem is the mason of fane, | His faith is dead, eyes set on others lane.
From his winking eyes it can be seen, | He is despaired of all godsend means.

text_blocks: From this poor man’s flame, sitting on his way | Bid him fiery conscience, the least I say.
Kindle his heart for a-long-lasting light, | From man’s hopes his hopes be more bright.
poems.full_text:
From this poor man’s flame, sitting on his way | Bid him fiery conscience, the least I say.
Kindle his heart for a-long-lasting light, | From man’s hopes his hopes be more bright.

text_blocks: Like gallants I fall and rise again, | What a blood I shed sans sword-and cane.
On every ones terrace now leans thy look, | For which a constant war I have to brook.
poems.full_text:
Like gallants I fall and rise again, | What a blood I shed sans sword-and cane.
On every ones terrace now leans thy look, | For which a constant war I have to brook.

text_blocks: Let me sob and sigh in a lone retreat, | How fine the Yasrib lines with no joint seat.
How odd a college looks to pub of thrill, | Tell me is this better or that one still.
poems.full_text:
Let me sob and sigh in a lone retreat, | How fine the Yasrib lines with no joint seat.
How odd a college looks to pub of thrill, | Tell me is this better or that one still.

text_blocks: I fly in the airy lovelier space, | My wings are getting wet from clouds I face.
I found in my conscience the Harem’s mould, | Since on my conscience that song had a hold.
poems.full_text:
I fly in the airy lovelier space, | My wings are getting wet from clouds I face.
I found in my conscience the Harem’s mould, | Since on my conscience that song had a hold.

text_blocks: Of secret I’told, they paid no heed, | They ate no fruits of vintage they need.
O nation’s chief do a justice to me, | As a writer of odes my friends call me.
poems.full_text:
Of secret I’told, they paid no heed, | They ate no fruits of vintage they need.
O nation’s chief do a justice to me, | As a writer of odes my friends call me.

text_blocks: To stick it to bosom this verse aims not, | With gems of meanings I open the knot.
With hope my passion would make it gold, | I temper their cuprum with heats manifold.
poems.full_text:
To stick it to bosom this verse aims not, | With gems of meanings I open the knot.
With hope my passion would make it gold, | I temper their cuprum with heats manifold.
phrases: cuprum:         Cuprum; copper, here it means personality and thinking.

text_blocks: You bid me for a theme on bliss life long, | On a dead ear sound a cheerful song.
Those uncouth put me in a poet’s hat, | To write a death date of this man or that.
poems.full_text:
You bid me for a theme on bliss life long, | On a dead ear sound a cheerful song.
Those uncouth put me in a poet’s hat, | To write a death date of this man or that.

text_blocks: My face looks saffron from arcane pain, | The blood looks oozing from red eyes veins.
The speech chokes throat and forms a knot, | I can’t speak though you know my lot.
poems.full_text:
My face looks saffron from arcane pain, | The blood looks oozing from red eyes veins.
The speech chokes throat and forms a knot, | I can’t speak though you know my lot.
phrases: arcane:         Arcane; hidden, known to chosen only; sec esoterics; hidden signs known by the few chosen (in mysticism)
lot.:         Here Iqbal is picturising a phase of direct link of one's heart with God, while talking in esoterics.

text_blocks: The meek utter hence of yonder glance, | Thus the ruthful dwell on sob’s parlance.
We keep eyes ope and seal the lips, | In mystics code speech is a slip.
poems.full_text:
The meek utter hence of yonder glance, | Thus the ruthful dwell on sob’s parlance.
We keep eyes ope and seal the lips, | In mystics code speech is a slip.
phrases: parlance.:         viz, in tears and sob's language.

text_blocks: Those who knew not I preached them ego, | For them I e’er caused my fonts to flow.
Bid me burning voice with whose sole flame, | All griefs are burnt save thy love’s sole aim.
poems.full_text:
Those who knew not I preached them ego, | For them I e’er caused my fonts to flow.
Bid me burning voice with whose sole flame, | All griefs are burnt save thy love’s sole aim.

text_blocks: What I hold in heart is grief and remorse. | Save thee I have no access and source.
My grief’s inner tale to whom I can tell, | You know in my bosom you only dwell.
poems.full_text:
What I hold in heart is grief and remorse. | Save thee I have no access and source.
My grief’s inner tale to whom I can tell, | You know in my bosom you only dwell.
phrases: remorse.:         The literal version of line. 1 and 2 is given below: [Save smoke of sighs we have nothing with us, Save thy own hand we have no access thus. Dud-i-Nafs; smoke of breath viz, sighs.]

text_blocks: A poor, ruthfull flutist1 who taught love’s tone, | Is melting himself in heat of songs own.
You know what he seeks and what he wants, | Yet he needs not both the worlds in grant.
poems.full_text:
A poor, ruthfull flutist1 who taught love’s tone, | Is melting himself in heat of songs own.
You know what he seeks and what he wants, | Yet he needs not both the worlds in grant.

text_blocks: I seek not my vigour from morning air, | From thy Sun’s boon I seek my growth and care.
My glance goes higher than stars and moon, | I write not verses for some one’s boon.
poems.full_text:
I seek not my vigour from morning air, | From thy Sun’s boon I seek my growth and care.
My glance goes higher than stars and moon, | I write not verses for some one’s boon.
phrases: vigour:         Nam-o-rang; moist and colour, lustre, beauty, freshness and form, as such vigour covers this sense.

text_blocks: I’am in a sea which has no coast side, | This heart is the lover’s path and guide.
For thy sake at Mecca a halt I make, | If not my journey was for thy sake.
poems.full_text:
I’am in a sea which has no coast side, | This heart is the lover’s path and guide.
For thy sake at Mecca a halt I make, | If not my journey was for thy sake.
phrases: path:         Dalil: path and guide.

text_blocks: Drive not from door who are longing for thee, | We are getting restive from thy flame’s glee.
So bid what ye wish, for patience ask, not, | Two hundred miles from it, the heart has brought.
poems.full_text:
Drive not from door who are longing for thee, | We are getting restive from thy flame’s glee.
So bid what ye wish, for patience ask, not, | Two hundred miles from it, the heart has brought.
phrases: glee.: The literal version of line 2 is given below: ['We can't calm the pathos you gave with glee.']

text_blocks: On idols white my heart is sweet, | It melts in Tina’s glamour’s heat.
So alien to self I made of me, | I sought of my ‘self’ but did not see.
poems.full_text:
On idols white my heart is sweet, | It melts in Tina’s glamour’s heat.
So alien to self I made of me, | I sought of my ‘self’ but did not see.
phrases: Tina’s:         Tina is a diminutive of Christina, a common name for a Christian girl, whose masculine gender is Christie, also a common name for a Christian. It was dim-cult to convey a true sense for Daeree of fane) in English, being a 'dichtomy' of 'masita' means one who belongs to mosque but he is not a maulvi. Similarly 'daeree' means who belongs to fane, not necessarily a priest.

text_blocks: From Western taverns the wines I take, | I buy for my head a great headache.
With the nobles of West I sat for days, | For me the worst days of my flameless stays.
poems.full_text:
From Western taverns the wines I take, | I buy for my head a great headache.
With the nobles of West I sat for days, | For me the worst days of my flameless stays.
phrases: wines:         The wines In Iqbal's own terminology it means the culture and civilization of a nation.

flameless:         Flameless (be soz) which means without flame of love and taste. Its synonym could be emotionless (though not used in English language. Unsparing nonchalant (without warmth), cool un-enthusiastic, insipid (lifeless) do not convey the sense of flameless (be soz).

text_blocks: I seek from thy door, whatever I seek, | Bid a grass leaf to peel a “Mountain’s” peak.
To me logic gave a headache great, | But a glance changed all over my fate.
poems.full_text:
I seek from thy door, whatever I seek, | Bid a grass leaf to peel a “Mountain’s” peak.
To me logic gave a headache great, | But a glance changed all over my fate.
phrases: leaf:         Grass leaf a poor man, to him (the poet).
“Mountain’s”:         Mountain a big power.

text_blocks: With ‘mullah’ or ‘Sufi’ I do not sit, | With this or that, you know I dont fit.
Thus write the word Allah on my heart’s slate, | To see ‘Him’ and Self in a lucent state.
poems.full_text:
With ‘mullah’ or ‘Sufi’ I do not sit, | With this or that, you know I dont fit.
Thus write the word Allah on my heart’s slate, | To see ‘Him’ and Self in a lucent state.

text_blocks: The ‘mullah’ never knows the pangs of grief, | No tears ever flow in his eyes and belief,
From his School of quacks I took to my heels, | The sounds of desert chants his dust can’t feel.
poems.full_text:
The ‘mullah’ never knows the pangs of grief, | No tears ever flow in his eyes and belief,
From his School of quacks I took to my heels, | The sounds of desert chants his dust can’t feel.
phrases: belief,:         Line 2 (Literal); His eyes thus lack a moist of the grief.
chants:         Zamzam Chant, here it means the sound of a chants of the caravans going to Holy land.

text_blocks: On pulpit his address a venom of bile, | In arms, hundred books to cover his wile.
In thy ‘own House’ I talk not in shame, | By himself though hid I feel His flame.
poems.full_text:
On pulpit his address a venom of bile, | In arms, hundred books to cover his wile.
In thy ‘own House’ I talk not in shame, | By himself though hid I feel His flame.

text_blocks: The heart of lucent hearts he took or I? | Thy message of love did he brought or I?
Two shafts of Deen’s quiver are ‘mullah’ and I, | Who took the right aim: did ‘mullah’ or I.
poems.full_text:
The heart of lucent hearts he took or I? | Thy message of love did he brought or I?
Two shafts of Deen’s quiver are ‘mullah’ and I, | Who took the right aim: did ‘mullah’ or I.
phrases: I?:         The underlying thought is given below in a verse: [Two shafts of envy are Mullah and I, Who took the right step did Mullah or I?] Here shaft means arrow or spear. (in figurative sense) as shafts of envy (or ridicule), means expressions of envy.

text_blocks: An alien I am within my own race, | To whom I should take the ‘Issues’ I face.
Those hidden pricks I fear to disclose, | I tell not my griefs to heart, though close.
poems.full_text:
An alien I am within my own race, | To whom I should take the ‘Issues’ I face.
Those hidden pricks I fear to disclose, | I tell not my griefs to heart, though close.
phrases: close.:         At last Iqbal feels that none is the friend of a man in this world save 'Allah' alone. Iqbal explains this theme in another couplet. [To know this seeker everyone failed, To whom what he said, from where be hailed?]

text_blocks: For any one’s boon this heart owes not, | With my own hand I opened each tough knot.
I banked on else once save Allah’s grace, | I fell hundred times from self’s high place
poems.full_text:
For any one’s boon this heart owes not, | With my own hand I opened each tough knot.
I banked on else once save Allah’s grace, | I fell hundred times from self’s high place
phrases: place:         Pearls (gauhar) in Persian also means intrinsic qualities (of a man) in figurative sense.

text_blocks: My craze still feels the same burning phase, | All the old passions are still ablaze.
From impact of old storms which I feel still, | The waves of my pearls get a new storm’s thrill.
poems.full_text:
My craze still feels the same burning phase, | All the old passions are still ablaze.
From impact of old storms which I feel still, | The waves of my pearls get a new storm’s thrill.
phrases: pearls:         Pearls (gauhar) in Persian also means intrinsic qualities (of a man) in figurative sense.

text_blocks: This dust still feels His living flame, | To midnight sighs, the heart still claims.
Cast Thy vision’s light so that I may see, | Though old I have courage to bear this glee.
poems.full_text:
This dust still feels His living flame, | To midnight sighs, the heart still claims.
Cast Thy vision’s light so that I may see, | Though old I have courage to bear this glee.

text_blocks: My glance looks not the world’s hollow game, | The heart is melting from inner flame.
I am in this world which, lacks any flame, | Tell me after all what is the secret game?
poems.full_text:
My glance looks not the world’s hollow game, | The heart is melting from inner flame.
I am in this world which, lacks any flame, | Tell me after all what is the secret game?

text_blocks: I have been born in a flameless age, | In me nature kept a fire ablaze.
The life in my neck is like a thread, | Say they are tighting this thread in my head.
poems.full_text:
I have been born in a flameless age, | In me nature kept a fire ablaze.
The life in my neck is like a thread, | Say they are tighting this thread in my head.
phrases: flameless:         In line 1, Iqbal has used the word 'flameless' age in a metaphorical sense. It, however, means faithless.
head.:         Iqbal says Say they are dragging me on cross, (is the literal translation) viz, to kill me. Here he is asking the Prophet to tell this state to God as a passionate appeal of a lover.

text_blocks: The ‘rose and poppy’ lack my ‘scent and shade. | All yearnings have died in a bosom fade.
In words, the grief hidden cannot contain, | If so, what to say, to whom to explain?
poems.full_text:
The ‘rose and poppy’ lack my ‘scent and shade. | All yearnings have died in a bosom fade.
In words, the grief hidden cannot contain, | If so, what to say, to whom to explain?
phrases: poppy’:          The 'rose' and 'poppy' (Gul-o-Lala) is an allusion, to members of his race.

shade.:         'Scent and shade', here it means my message. In his last days this thought was always pinching his heart that his nation treats him only as a poet. As such she is paying no attention to his message. As a last resort this lover of the Prophet is making this appeal to the Holy Prophet, which no doubt is the Qibla and Kaa'ba of each Muslim, against a background of the Political affairs between 1927-37.
fade.:         viz, faded

text_blocks: So alien I am in West and East, | No confidants true I have the least.
To heart I’m telling my sorrowful mood, | To cheat my solitude, like child I brood.
poems.full_text:
So alien I am in West and East, | No confidants true I have the least.
To heart I’m telling my sorrowful mood, | To cheat my solitude, like child I brood.
phrases: brood.:         This is Iqbal's soliloquy to himself, when he is feeling himself alone without alter egos (friends) to have a tete-a-tete talk. Here alien means lonely. (Soliloquy; talk to one's self.)

text_blocks: I broke the magic of the modern age, | I pounced on the grains and broke the trap cage.
The God knows that in the Abram’s wake, | How fearless I sat in that fire’s stake.
poems.full_text:
I broke the magic of the modern age, | I pounced on the grains and broke the trap cage.
The God knows that in the Abram’s wake, | How fearless I sat in that fire’s stake.
phrases: stake.:         Abraham or Abram, dim; Abe; (for lbrahim). Stake, a post to which a person was tied, in olden days before being burned to death as a punishment for heresy.

text_blocks: You have lit up my eyes with an insight, | To thee owes hence, the Lailah’s light,
Bring a Dawn for me, with Thy Vision’s Scene, | My night gets thy light, like moonlight sheen.
poems.full_text:
You have lit up my eyes with an insight, | To thee owes hence, the Lailah’s light,
Bring a Dawn for me, with Thy Vision’s Scene, | My night gets thy light, like moonlight sheen.
phrases: sheen.:         The origin of the Prophet's being owes to the light (noor) of God. Noor means 'Shine and Sheen', fire in the distance bloom, blossom, light, God's enlightenment. Thus every Prophet has a peculiar 'floor' of Allah which can he seen from earth to heaven when God wishes so. There is a Hadith of Allah's Prophet Whosoever saw me he saw the Almighty.

text_blocks: When I pressed myself in my own embrace, | Then I saw my place with thy light’s grace.
In this fane old with the morning tears mere, | A world of love and daze lo I cause here.
poems.full_text:
When I pressed myself in my own embrace, | Then I saw my place with thy light’s grace.
In this fane old with the morning tears mere, | A world of love and daze lo I cause here.
phrases: here.: The essence of line 1 and 2 is given in a verse of Iqbal whose translation (by me) has been published in the Pakistan Review of April, 1966, is given below: [Through a reverie of thy soul, Find the Secret of the-world-whole. Either you, take me on thy side ]

text_blocks: The world has charms like paradise true; | My tears give a moist to the shoots too.
She lacks to her part that cry and hue, | She’s looking for a man for guidance true.
poems.full_text:
The world has charms like paradise true; | My tears give a moist to the shoots too.
She lacks to her part that cry and hue, | She’s looking for a man for guidance true.
phrases: true.:         Basic thought: The nation is not in a position to cause a revolution in this world. She is too weak for any important activity (for a cataclysmic change).

text_blocks: Bid him O lord! a holy man’s lead, | Who is proud of his ‘home made wine’s need.
Like Hyder, the Lion whose arms are strong, | For both world’s wealth he would never long.
poems.full_text:
Bid him O lord! a holy man’s lead, | Who is proud of his ‘home made wine’s need.
Like Hyder, the Lion whose arms are strong, | For both world’s wealth he would never long.
phrases: need.:          Home made wine In Iqbal's own terminology this term applies to Islamic traditions, culture and civilization.

text_blocks: Move around O bearer! the wine cup’s course, | From wine give the flute further burning force.
Bid me a heart in the bosom of mine, | Who can take tussels with the Kaisers line.
poems.full_text:
Move around O bearer! the wine cup’s course, | From wine give the flute further burning force.
Bid me a heart in the bosom of mine, | Who can take tussels with the Kaisers line.

text_blocks: For love the world came from thee the love’s flame, | In love the hidden joy thy old wine’s game.
I know only one thing from the Gabe’s tune, | That he took his glamour from thy moon’s boon.
poems.full_text:
For love the world came from thee the love’s flame, | In love the hidden joy thy old wine’s game.
I know only one thing from the Gabe’s tune, | That he took his glamour from thy moon’s boon.

text_blocks: To me this burning a boon of thy glow, | Thy font’s wine is waving in my vine so.
In shame the Join’s realm to my content bows, | With thee as my heart had tete-a-tete close.
poems.full_text:
To me this burning a boon of thy glow, | Thy font’s wine is waving in my vine so.
In shame the Join’s realm to my content bows, | With thee as my heart had tete-a-tete close.
phrases: close.:         The underlying thought Iqbal says in a verse in Bal-e-Jibreel: [The Jum feels small at my content's fame, As my heart is beating in thy love's flame. To Dara and Eck that dervesh is great, In want who can keep a lion's pluck and trait. ]

text_blocks: This heart, I tied not with aught in this fane, | I lost self’s place in my own eye’s pane.
Now he is looking for my ‘bows’ today, | On whom I was ruling just the last day.
poems.full_text:
This heart, I tied not with aught in this fane, | I lost self’s place in my own eye’s pane.
Now he is looking for my ‘bows’ today, | On whom I was ruling just the last day.
phrases: day.:         Line 3 and 4 (Literal): [That idol seeks now my kowtows today, To whom I had broken just the last day.]

text_blocks: Grow that poppy from the dust of mine, | Whose blood is dripping from my heart’s line.
This heart be received as a favour great, | I have no fine offer than heart in plate.
poems.full_text:
Grow that poppy from the dust of mine, | Whose blood is dripping from my heart’s line.
This heart be received as a favour great, | I have no fine offer than heart in plate.
phrases: poppy:         Here poppy mean a lover's heart in Iqbal's own terminology which he wants to present to his beloved in a plate

text_blocks: To my shining race I would love to groan, | With new melting thought full of moaning tone.
The etiquette calls for a brief parlance, | I groan, making tones and wish a rest hence.
poems.full_text:
To my shining race I would love to groan, | With new melting thought full of moaning tone.
The etiquette calls for a brief parlance, | I groan, making tones and wish a rest hence.
phrases: hence.:         The literal translation of line 2 is also very fine, viz. Line 2, I carve melting thoughts full of moaning tone. Line 4, means after all this I wish to die, I wish an eternal rest. This quatrain is a very good example of an impossible plain version called in Urdu and Persian a Sihl-i-mumtana (1. easy, 2. impossible, inaccessible). According to Webster's Dictionary: Parlance (Archaic:) conversation esp parley or debate. 2. (not archaic), a style or manner of speaking or writing; language, idiom as a military parlance.

text_blocks: For the sake of truth of my free lance tone, | For the sake of my sighs impatient groan.
For them I pray for clouds of vernal rain, | Who made a best use of my fruits and grains.
poems.full_text:
For the sake of truth of my free lance tone, | For the sake of my sighs impatient groan.
For them I pray for clouds of vernal rain, | Who made a best use of my fruits and grains.
phrases: grains.:         Line 3 (Literal) For that dust I pray for clouds of vernal rain.

text_blocks: I hold a heart in hand find not a beau, | A treasure I have but no robbers Lo;
I pray thee to make in my heart a place, | How much lonely I am there is no case.
poems.full_text:
I hold a heart in hand find not a beau, | A treasure I have but no robbers Lo;
I pray thee to make in my heart a place, | How much lonely I am there is no case.
phrases: case.:         Lonely (adj. ) means alone, solitary, isolated, unhappy as being alone, longing for friends' company. Lonesome (adj. ) having or causing a lonely feeling, unfrequented, desolate n. (colloq.); self, as all by my lonesome. The readers may use lonesome or lonely as they like.

text_blocks: Like Rumi I raised His call in Harem whole, | From whom I learnt secret knowledge of soul.
He passed through the crises of his time, | I am going too through crisis and crime.
poems.full_text:
Like Rumi I raised His call in Harem whole, | From whom I learnt secret knowledge of soul.
He passed through the crises of his time, | I am going too through crisis and crime.
phrases: crime.:         The simple and literal translation of line 3 and 4 is given below: [An old time of crisis he had seen, Through this age of crisis I have been]

text_blocks: Raise a garden new from dust of mine, | Mix a poppy’s blood to my tears shine.
If I’m not fit for Hyder’s sword and lance, | As sharp as his lance give me a glance.
poems.full_text:
Raise a garden new from dust of mine, | Mix a poppy’s blood to my tears shine.
If I’m not fit for Hyder’s sword and lance, | As sharp as his lance give me a glance.
phrases: glance.:         Hyder lion, as obriquet or nickname) of Hazrat Ali, the 4th Caliph after the Prophet.

text_blocks: A Muslim is resting from coast to coast, | On self he lost hopes, is shy of sea most.
Save this poor soul a pathos who keeps, | Who sees hidden wounds1 when his heart weeps.
poems.full_text:
A Muslim is resting from coast to coast, | On self he lost hopes, is shy of sea most.
Save this poor soul a pathos who keeps, | Who sees hidden wounds1 when his heart weeps.

text_blocks: Who told him I smell thee ‘under the rose’, | To give him good news of a spring tide close.
When I saw not in him thy old flame’s blaze, | With a new spark I set his caneswood ablaze.
poems.full_text:
Who told him I smell thee ‘under the rose’, | To give him good news of a spring tide close.
When I saw not in him thy old flame’s blaze, | With a new spark I set his caneswood ablaze.
phrases: ablaze.: Iqbal is addressing the Holy Prophet, "I have given them (my nation) a new hope to receive the Prophet's flame of love inspite of the fact that She is passing though a process of decline, I have told them not to be disappointed."

text_blocks: From thy own main give pearls to my rill, | My gems to each door, each land and hill.
That gale did not ope my heart’s shut door, | Bid a verve anew and a gale more.
poems.full_text:
From thy own main give pearls to my rill, | My gems to each door, each land and hill.
That gale did not ope my heart’s shut door, | Bid a verve anew and a gale more.
phrases: more.:         Basic thought (A lover is never satisfied with one glance of the beloved. As such the poet(the lover is craving for more and more, a new glimpse ever).

text_blocks: In a gathering see my flute’s tones sweet, | And self-melting phase in a lone retreat.
I learnt the Faqr’s’ path from fore-father’s trait, | To care not ever for any king great.
poems.full_text:
In a gathering see my flute’s tones sweet, | And self-melting phase in a lone retreat.
I learnt the Faqr’s’ path from fore-father’s trait, | To care not ever for any king great.
phrases: phase:         Phase state.
Faqr’s’:         'faqr'; content.
great.:         'Nukta-i-faqr' as used by Iqbal means witty saying; anecdote.

text_blocks: I kept beaming face in this or that case, | I raised the old veils from the meaning face.
At such a high pitch to craves I brought, | That one breath I had the other had not.
poems.full_text:
I kept beaming face in this or that case, | I raised the old veils from the meaning face.
At such a high pitch to craves I brought, | That one breath I had the other had not.
phrases: not.:         Here craves means verve; excitement.

text_blocks: I have shared the poppy’s flame and pain, | To conscience of life I woke up again.
I know not whom I taught a zealous tone , | As I was alone, and harping alone.
poems.full_text:
I have shared the poppy’s flame and pain, | To conscience of life I woke up again.
I know not whom I taught a zealous tone , | As I was alone, and harping alone.
phrases: poppy’s:         Poppy; each man (of the nation)
conscience:         Conscience of life =its truth and realities.
tone:         Nukta-i-Shauq, a tip of ardent longings, a zealous briefing.

text_blocks: With thy light alone I lit up my glance, | I make a peep through the sun and moon hence.
Saying I’m Muslim I shudder with shame, | I know the hard task of Lailah’s name.
poems.full_text:
With thy light alone I lit up my glance, | I make a peep through the sun and moon hence.
Saying I’m Muslim I shudder with shame, | I know the hard task of Lailah’s name.

text_blocks: I need in thy land just a melting sigh, | To me this is first and last aim to die.
Ho! the daring sot who said to Gods Grace, | I need from Thee only Mustafa’s face.
poems.full_text:
I need in thy land just a melting sigh, | To me this is first and last aim to die.
Ho! the daring sot who said to Gods Grace, | I need from Thee only Mustafa’s face.

text_blocks: I hold very dear that roaring roar, | Which cuts a spring from mountain core.
For Javed I cherish and crave the same, | From Thy love he gets his grandeur and fame.
poems.full_text:
I hold very dear that roaring roar, | Which cuts a spring from mountain core.
For Javed I cherish and crave the same, | From Thy love he gets his grandeur and fame.
phrases: fame.:         Ha-o-hu-ai, means noise, hustle and hustle, uproar but here it means force.

text_blocks: Look to these saucy anglican maids, | As if Suns and moons have come for raids.
My simple young nation keeps a blood warm, | Beware! the heathen eye’s sensual storm
poems.full_text:
Look to these saucy anglican maids, | As if Suns and moons have come for raids.
My simple young nation keeps a blood warm, | Beware! the heathen eye’s sensual storm
phrases: storm:         The above quatrain (twin couplet) is addressed to his son Javed, when he was a few English girls in almost nude dress. Kaj Kullah also means beloved, a king, a title of Persian Kings prior to Muslim era.

text_blocks: Give a helping hand to those who are weak, | They look not to aught, but Allah they seek.
From that fire’s flame which kindled my heart, | Bid the Muslim boys a wee bit part.
poems.full_text:
Give a helping hand to those who are weak, | They look not to aught, but Allah they seek.
From that fire’s flame which kindled my heart, | Bid the Muslim boys a wee bit part.
phrases: part.:         Wee bit a little.

text_blocks: You too take the wine from friend’s cup warm, | To be for ever in the friend’s arm.
No bows are these O, ‘Aziz of Arab land’, | From eyelash I’m dusting my friend’s door sand,
poems.full_text:
You too take the wine from friend’s cup warm, | To be for ever in the friend’s arm.
No bows are these O, ‘Aziz of Arab land’, | From eyelash I’m dusting my friend’s door sand,
phrases: sand,:         Eyelash (Sing=here Iqbal has also used mizah eyelash and not mizgan (P1 of miza). Moreover Eyelash means one hair or the row of hairs, on the edge of the eyelid

text_blocks: A poor man I’m, you hold the ‘Arab’s reign, | I hold a king’s place in meaning’s domain.
A world which grew up from ‘Lailah’s’ seed, | Its root are quite deep in my faith and creed.
poems.full_text:
A poor man I’m, you hold the ‘Arab’s reign, | I hold a king’s place in meaning’s domain.
A world which grew up from ‘Lailah’s’ seed, | Its root are quite deep in my faith and creed.

text_blocks: A look of pain I’m and see no cure quick, | I boast not but weep being old, weak and sick.
I’m lost arrow though, put in nation’s bow, | Use me again if the nation thinks so,
poems.full_text:
A look of pain I’m and see no cure quick, | I boast not but weep being old, weak and sick.
I’m lost arrow though, put in nation’s bow, | Use me again if the nation thinks so,

text_blocks: Let tis join hands to spread his love’s flame. | Leave the world whole and work not for fame.
Within the holy walls of the friend’s home, | Till tears flow blood, dance around his dome.
poems.full_text:
Let tis join hands to spread his love’s flame. | Leave the world whole and work not for fame.
Within the holy walls of the friend’s home, | Till tears flow blood, dance around his dome.

text_blocks: You hold a high place in the desert’s land, | Whose eyes are bright like a mirror house grand.
Where e’er you wish you may pitch up the tents. | But ban a feast there if the tent chords are lent.
poems.full_text:
You hold a high place in the desert’s land, | Whose eyes are bright like a mirror house grand.
Where e’er you wish you may pitch up the tents. | But ban a feast there if the tent chords are lent.
phrases: lent.:         Line 2 (Literal): whose eve like dawn is a mirror house grand.

text_blocks: Being Muslims we make no home and false ties, | From a circle aloof, we are nine skies.
He taught us a kowtow from which we knows | The price of each god to whom the men how.
poems.full_text:
Being Muslims we make no home and false ties, | From a circle aloof, we are nine skies.
He taught us a kowtow from which we knows | The price of each god to whom the men how.

text_blocks: To anglian idols pay not a heed, | The worth of her bonds is not a malt’s seed.
From the Farooq’s bold eyes borrow a glance, | Make a fearless jump in the new age hence.
poems.full_text:
To anglian idols pay not a heed, | The worth of her bonds is not a malt’s seed.
From the Farooq’s bold eyes borrow a glance, | Make a fearless jump in the new age hence.
phrases: hence.:         (1) Beganah; like a stranger. (2) Paiman; (Persian:) promise, oath, treaty.

text_blocks: The gnostic’s verses seek not of me, | I hold the nature of beaux like thee.
I shed in this garden my red tears rain, | Like pearls of dew drops, falling grain by grain.
poems.full_text:
The gnostic’s verses seek not of me, | I hold the nature of beaux like thee.
I shed in this garden my red tears rain, | Like pearls of dew drops, falling grain by grain.

text_blocks: Be nearer to the aim like a moon new, | Seek the higher heights with efforts anew.
A place in this lane if you wish to make, | Make a tie with God in the Prophet’s wake.
poems.full_text:
Be nearer to the aim like a moon new, | Seek the higher heights with efforts anew.
A place in this lane if you wish to make, | Make a tie with God in the Prophet’s wake.
phrases: wake.:         Basic ideas Seek a tete-a-tete with God in the Prophet's wake. The ultimate aim of each faithful (without distinction of cast and creed) is tete-a-tete with God or the Wisal-i-Ilahi, for which Raza-j-Ilahj is a must. The Namaz, Roza and Zikr are the necessary vehicles through which we strive to achieve the ultimate aim of Visal-j-llahi. (Tete.a-tete of God is more appropriate than union here). Raza-i-Ilahi, means) pleasure of God.

text_blocks: My self’s own sea gave a rise to me, | It sharpen’d my wits like pearls in sea.
On me that ‘Nimrod’ is boiling with rage. | Fm trying to build up ‘Harem’s’ image.
poems.full_text:
My self’s own sea gave a rise to me, | It sharpen’d my wits like pearls in sea.
On me that ‘Nimrod’ is boiling with rage. | Fm trying to build up ‘Harem’s’ image.
phrases: image.:         Bakhud paecheedgan; According to a contemporary scholar it means to fortify and cultivate one's own self; strong thing of one's own ego. I also understand its meanings are self seeing (though literal meanings are self-writhing's Self coiling viz, the philosophers and other thinkers. Nimrods viz, the Nimrods and Pharoahs (Feros) of this age, the enemies of faith. Baleedan, to grow, to rise.

text_blocks: Come O’ bearer and move the cup of Wine, | And leave the worlds both under long veils line,
He raised all the curtains before this sot, | The codes of His Path the ‘Mullah’ knew not.
poems.full_text:
Come O’ bearer and move the cup of Wine, | And leave the worlds both under long veils line,
He raised all the curtains before this sot, | The codes of His Path the ‘Mullah’ knew not.
phrases: not.:         Here 'bearer' means Iqbal's own preceptor and religious guide.

text_blocks: Come O’ bearer and raise the veils aside, | Cause my heart’s blood’ dripping from the eyes side.
From a tone which gives no East or. West trace, | Send a ‘no fear note’ from the ‘no fear place.’
poems.full_text:
Come O’ bearer and raise the veils aside, | Cause my heart’s blood’ dripping from the eyes side.
From a tone which gives no East or. West trace, | Send a ‘no fear note’ from the ‘no fear place.’
phrases: place.’:         Line 3: here East or West mean Eastern or Western (tune). Line 4, Send a 'La takhaf' note from its place, was the best literal translation (Latakhaf means fear not) as it was addressed to Moses by God.

text_blocks: Raise from thy bosom a ‘Call of God Great’, | Hit thy own exir on thy dusty fate.
Gaurd thy ego ever, lead a life nice, | To none give thy luck at any great price.
poems.full_text:
Raise from thy bosom a ‘Call of God Great’, | Hit thy own exir on thy dusty fate.
Gaurd thy ego ever, lead a life nice, | To none give thy luck at any great price.
phrases: price.:         Line 2 means "From thy own dust (dusty fate) make thy ow nexir". A call of God Great; viz. Takbir (of Arabic).

text_blocks: From self a Muslim is man perfect | He is slave when it dies in heart in fact.
If you take thy ‘self’, ‘a priceless’ lot, | To look save Thee is a tabood thought.
poems.full_text:
From self a Muslim is man perfect | He is slave when it dies in heart in fact.
If you take thy ‘self’, ‘a priceless’ lot, | To look save Thee is a tabood thought.

text_blocks: As long the Muslim, in self can peep, | Like pearls they rest in the oceans deep.
From ego if you ran in this fane, | Your own death you buy for life’s bargain.
poems.full_text:
As long the Muslim, in self can peep, | Like pearls they rest in the oceans deep.
From ego if you ran in this fane, | Your own death you buy for life’s bargain.
phrases: bargain.:         Basic thought: [Thus the Ego's price he forgot when, He took his own life with own hands then.]

text_blocks: The veils of thy fortune lo! I ope, | Take the Prophet’s path give up no hope.
If you believe not whatever I say, | Give up the faith and die in Kafir’s way.
poems.full_text:
The veils of thy fortune lo! I ope, | Take the Prophet’s path give up no hope.
If you believe not whatever I say, | Give up the faith and die in Kafir’s way.

text_blocks: Now all the shut doors for Turks are ope. | The Egypt’s base would be firm I hope.
You give a rap too at the Ego’s door, | None knew without it his faith and land’s lore
poems.full_text:
Now all the shut doors for Turks are ope. | The Egypt’s base would be firm I hope.
You give a rap too at the Ego’s door, | None knew without it his faith and land’s lore

text_blocks: A nation whose spring falls to decay, | She always craves for the good old days.
A poppy grows though from her dusty gems, | It also takes a gown of fading stems.
poems.full_text:
A nation whose spring falls to decay, | She always craves for the good old days.
A poppy grows though from her dusty gems, | It also takes a gown of fading stems.
phrases: stems.:         Here poppy means a young man (of that nation), when every young man of a nation falls a prey to disappointment and makes no efforts for his revival. As such the nations can regain their lost prestige by efforts alone. 'His' colour is pale due to disappointments of life.

text_blocks: God gave that nation a sway o’er lands, | Who shaped her fortunes with her hands.
With that nation he keeps no links. | Whose farmer tills for other’s drinks
poems.full_text:
God gave that nation a sway o’er lands, | Who shaped her fortunes with her hands.
With that nation he keeps no links. | Whose farmer tills for other’s drinks

text_blocks: From Razi thus learn the Quran’s insight, | From his lamp he lit up his own lamp’s light.
But a point from me you must learn hence, | That can’t be life, lacking flame and trance.
poems.full_text:
From Razi thus learn the Quran’s insight, | From his lamp he lit up his own lamp’s light.
But a point from me you must learn hence, | That can’t be life, lacking flame and trance.
phrases: trance.:         Viz. No life is life without the Prophet's flame of love burning in his heart.

text_blocks: Who makes Ego firm by ‘Lailah’s tie, | From lifeless sands can make a seeing eye.
Lose not ever that man’s greatest boon, | In whose reach I see the Sun and Moon.
poems.full_text:
Who makes Ego firm by ‘Lailah’s tie, | From lifeless sands can make a seeing eye.
Lose not ever that man’s greatest boon, | In whose reach I see the Sun and Moon.
phrases: Moon.:         Bisic thought Iqbal has been looking for a fit man always and here he pinpoints the qualities of that great man

text_blocks: O ignorant man get a knowing heart, | In wake of thy elders learn thy own part.
Flow can a ‘momin’ tell His Secret act, | From ‘La’ got the Allah’s positive fact’.
poems.full_text:
O ignorant man get a knowing heart, | In wake of thy elders learn thy own part.
Flow can a ‘momin’ tell His Secret act, | From ‘La’ got the Allah’s positive fact’.
phrases: fact’.:         'La' is an ahbrev of 'La ilah-a-ill-Allah'. viz: No god exists there save the Allah Himself.

text_blocks: Thy heart keeps not that hidden scar. | A Muslim’s shine it lacks so far.
You always water the Soil of Ego, | From a lake which knows no furious flow:
poems.full_text:
Thy heart keeps not that hidden scar. | A Muslim’s shine it lacks so far.
You always water the Soil of Ego, | From a lake which knows no furious flow:
phrases: flow::          Line 4: (Literal), From a lake which knows no flood and l)illo\v. (billow), n. (Lit:) great wave which sweeps every thing.

text_blocks: A place of I am God is God’s own place. | This sin takes to gallows or no disgrace?
If one man says this reprove at this wrong, | If a nation says, then you get along.
poems.full_text:
A place of I am God is God’s own place. | This sin takes to gallows or no disgrace?
If one man says this reprove at this wrong, | If a nation says, then you get along.
phrases: gallows:         Line 2 means: This sin takes to gallows or just gets grace. It refers to 'Ana-al-Haq' of Mansoor Hallaj.

text_blocks: I am the God suits to that nation lone, | Whose blood’s moisture feels each branch grown.
In whose power hids a beauty queer, | To him the nine heavens are servants clear.
poems.full_text:
I am the God suits to that nation lone, | Whose blood’s moisture feels each branch grown.
In whose power hids a beauty queer, | To him the nine heavens are servants clear.

text_blocks: Among nations large she holds a place great, | That race is the leader of both worlds’ fate.
From her novel acts, new miracles breed, | To dream and weaken is banned in her creed.
poems.full_text:
Among nations large she holds a place great, | That race is the leader of both worlds’ fate.
From her novel acts, new miracles breed, | To dream and weaken is banned in her creed.
phrases: creed.:         Literal version of Line 3 and 4 is as follows Here Iqbal is condemning Sukr or stupor. He makes new things and gives new thoughts, To him is banned to dream and rot.

text_blocks: From her inner verve that race is a flame, | To her the world charms is a worthless game.
What means by I’m God her efforts define, | Her each “Kun”/“be” says “Yakun”/”become” an object fine.
poems.full_text:
From her inner verve that race is a flame, | To her the world charms is a worthless game.
What means by I’m God her efforts define, | Her each “Kun”/“be” says “Yakun”/”become” an object fine.
phrases: fine.:         Basic thoughts This world came into being (in six days) when the God said Kun (be), the God's 'Kun' thus turned into a 'became'.

text_blocks: Like a unique race thus She flies in space, | With eyes ever set on her centre’s base.
The moon and stars in her lasso’s reach , | Lies in her hand the fate of age each.
poems.full_text:
Like a unique race thus She flies in space, | With eyes ever set on her centre’s base.
The moon and stars in her lasso’s reach , | Lies in her hand the fate of age each.
phrases: reach:         Line 3 In her lasso reach, viz. = in her easy reach.

text_blocks: In garden’s lawn he is song bird sweet, | In jungles a hawk with ruthless heat.
Her king in power is a poor man’s base, | Her poor man in want has a kingly grace.
poems.full_text:
In garden’s lawn he is song bird sweet, | In jungles a hawk with ruthless heat.
Her king in power is a poor man’s base, | Her poor man in want has a kingly grace.

text_blocks: Fill the old wine in the New Age bowl. | Cast the self’s light on hills and lands whole.
If you wish to eat fruits from Mansoor’s bowl, | Say none save Allah can rule the world whole.
poems.full_text:
Fill the old wine in the New Age bowl. | Cast the self’s light on hills and lands whole.
If you wish to eat fruits from Mansoor’s bowl, | Say none save Allah can rule the world whole.
phrases: whole.:         Basic thought: [Take the world's order in you own hand, Throw other Gods from your heart's land.] Hussain bin Mansoor Hallaj, a famous saint who was hanged on gibbot in 309 Hijri for saying 'Anal Haq' I am the Truth; I am the God) His real name was Hussain, but known as Mansoor Hallaj on his father's name. He was not a Hallaj (a cotton carder) by profession. Once he stayed at the house of a friend (who was a cotton carder) in his absence. On his own hint (or gesture) the carding bow started carding automatically. From that day be was named Hallaj.

text_blocks: The Mullah and Sufi are cross in deed, | His eye seldom sees the pitch in its seed.
If this is the faith which I have in me, | To oust me from Kaaba a right has he.
poems.full_text:
The Mullah and Sufi are cross in deed, | His eye seldom sees the pitch in its seed.
If this is the faith which I have in me, | To oust me from Kaaba a right has he.
phrases: he.:         The 2nd idiomatic version of line 1 and 2 is as follows: "The Mullah and Sufi wear a long face", He makes no nuance in sweet or sour trace

text_blocks: When the English subdued the mosque and fane, | “No aliens are they”, said the convent’s brain.
I told my fears to a Mullah when, | “Make his end well”, he just prayed then.
poems.full_text:
When the English subdued the mosque and fane, | “No aliens are they”, said the convent’s brain.
I told my fears to a Mullah when, | “Make his end well”, he just prayed then.
phrases: then.:         Convent; a Khanqah or monastry.

text_blocks: To Mullah and Sufi thou art a slave, | From insight of Quran no life you crave.
You need verses only at time of grief, | That ‘Yasin’ would give death paugs a relief.
poems.full_text:
To Mullah and Sufi thou art a slave, | From insight of Quran no life you crave.
You need verses only at time of grief, | That ‘Yasin’ would give death paugs a relief.
phrases: relief.:         The above mentioned twin couplet of Iqbal reminds another verse about the Mullah. He is bet in himself, how can he lead.

text_blocks: Through the mirror of Quran see thy deeds, | How changed it thee, change the life you lead.
Thus weigh in a scale thy actions and thought, | Get a sweeping change as the elders brought.
poems.full_text:
Through the mirror of Quran see thy deeds, | How changed it thee, change the life you lead.
Thus weigh in a scale thy actions and thought, | Get a sweeping change as the elders brought.

text_blocks: I salute the Mullah and Sufi old, | Who gave me the message of God as told.
It tilled with wonder the meaning he drew, | Which God, His Prophet and Gabe never knew.
poems.full_text:
I salute the Mullah and Sufi old, | Who gave me the message of God as told.
It tilled with wonder the meaning he drew, | Which God, His Prophet and Gabe never knew.

text_blocks: On hell kafir-maker Mullah spoke, | On which a kafir in a nice way broke.
That slave knows not where he would go? | Who is sending the rest in heirs long row.
poems.full_text:
On hell kafir-maker Mullah spoke, | On which a kafir in a nice way broke.
That slave knows not where he would go? | Who is sending the rest in heirs long row.
phrases: row.:         As we say he broke out into curses, (on which a Kafir gave him a poke), is the vulgar sense of it.

text_blocks: A well read disciple asked his guide, | With a word in which a sting did hide.
To die for a life will it well behave? | To make one’s living from bones of a grave.
poems.full_text:
A well read disciple asked his guide, | With a word in which a sting did hide.
To die for a life will it well behave? | To make one’s living from bones of a grave.

text_blocks: Thus spoke to his son a guide in patched robe, | I tell thee a point after whole life’s probe.
To Nimrods of this age, know by face, | By God’s grace live with the Abram’s grace.
poems.full_text:
Thus spoke to his son a guide in patched robe, | I tell thee a point after whole life’s probe.
To Nimrods of this age, know by face, | By God’s grace live with the Abram’s grace.

text_blocks: Pour in thy self that old wine again, | His one cup’s worth is more than a reign.
Keep the verses of Rumi in thy brain, | And paste them around the heart’s walls again.
poems.full_text:
Pour in thy self that old wine again, | His one cup’s worth is more than a reign.
Keep the verses of Rumi in thy brain, | And paste them around the heart’s walls again.

text_blocks: Take from his cup those poppy like stems, | Whose one sip can turn a stone into gem.
The heart of a lion who gave to the deer, | Who shaved the black spots from a panther’s rear.
poems.full_text:
Take from his cup those poppy like stems, | Whose one sip can turn a stone into gem.
The heart of a lion who gave to the deer, | Who shaved the black spots from a panther’s rear.

text_blocks: From his verve and heat I got a good share, | My night was a day from that bught star’s flare,
See a gazelle on ‘Harem’s’ desert sands, | He smiles like a lion on oasis or lands.
poems.full_text:
From his verve and heat I got a good share, | My night was a day from that bught star’s flare,
See a gazelle on ‘Harem’s’ desert sands, | He smiles like a lion on oasis or lands.

text_blocks: Being full of pathos and passion’s heat, | His tete-a-tete thus had the pangs sweet treat.
By flute gets beauty of His Love’s sweet light, | A gift and share good of His Glory and Might.
poems.full_text:
Being full of pathos and passion’s heat, | His tete-a-tete thus had the pangs sweet treat.
By flute gets beauty of His Love’s sweet light, | A gift and share good of His Glory and Might.
